title: R41131
content: The alternate engine program for the F-35 Lightning II fighter was a significant issue for Congress in FY2012, with implications for the defense budget and military capability. The program developed the General Electric/Rolls-Royce F136 engine as an alternative to the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine. Congress rejected proposals to terminate the program in previous budgets and provided funding to continue it. The General Electric/Rolls-Royce F136 engine was developed as an alternative to the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine for the F-35 fighter. Despite Congress rejecting proposals to terminate the program in previous budgets, funding for the alternate engine program was eliminated in the final FY2011 DOD budget. General Electric and Rolls-Royce announced the termination of the F136 engine development on December 2, 2011, ending the F-35 engine competition. The budget submission proposed to terminate the alternate engine program, and Congress eliminated funding for it in the final FY2011 DOD budget. General Electric and Rolls-Royce ended development of the F136 engine, terminating the F-35 engine competition. The Department of Defense selected the Lockheed Martin F-35 with the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine as the winner of the JSF competition. Congress required development of an alternate engine, the F136, which was later terminated in FY2011. The F136 engine, developed by General Electric and Rolls-Royce for the F-35, was designed to be used interchangeably with the F135 engine without modifying the airframe. The F136 engine, developed by General Electric and Rolls-Royce for the F-35, faced proposed terminations by the Administration in multiple fiscal years. However, Congress restored funding for the program due to the progress of the main engine and cost analysis.
